description: Pre-test for type to chart scenario - assesses baseline understanding of pairing data types with charts

questions.question_text: You have monthly revenue data over 2 years. Which chart type is most appropriate?
questions.explanation: Line charts are ideal for temporal/time-series data to show trends over time.

questions.question_text: You need to compare sales across 5 different product categories. Which chart is best?
questions.explanation: Bar or column charts are ideal for comparing categorical data across different groups.

questions.question_text: What is a key problem with using a pie chart when you have 15 categories?

options.text: Pie charts don't support that many slices
Too many slices make the chart hard to read and compare
Pie charts only work with temporal data
There is no problem - pie charts scale well

questions.explanation: Pie charts become cluttered and difficult to interpret with many categories, making comparisons challenging.

questions.question_text: Someone wants to use a line chart to show customer segments 'Gold', 'Silver', 'Bronze'. What's the issue?

options.text: Line charts should be used for continuous or temporal data, not unordered categories
Line charts work fine for any categorical data
The segment names are too long

questions.explanation: Line charts imply continuity or progression, which doesn't make sense for unordered categorical data like customer segments.
